ask for corrections um you know find out how they've you know

act and the it rules um have had significant limitations um again they're not
they're not specifically designed for privacy they were designed for data as their name suggests they've come out of i.t legislation um not not privacy not this
sort of you know fundamental human right that's if you look at where the gdpr has come from you know the eu the european union
enshrined privacy as a fundamental human right i think back in the 50s so this is a
different world that we're operating in here so the it act it rules not specifically designed for privacy
the scope and applicability of it is very narrow it only applies to private organizations to which you've
got a contractual arrangement with them so if they're collecting your data without a contractual arrangement the law doesn't apply
it also is a very clear that it doesn't apply to any kind of government or state agencies
that are using information um so however india is changing though so
in 2017 there was a landmark judgment in the supreme court of india um where the court actually held that
the right to privacy is a fundamental right under the instant indian indian constitution
and because it was considered a part of the right to life and the right to personal liberty
so in justice ks put aswami and others and the union of india in 2017 the court
actually stated that every person should have the right to control commercial use of their identity
and the right of individuals to exclusively commercially exploit their identity and personal information
to control the information that is available out about them on the internet and to disseminate certain personal
information for limited purposes actually emanate from that right privacy
so that was that was a landmark case that was the first time you know this has been recognized as a
fundamental human right in india um and that was you know quite a significant change in thinking
but the um because the court was looking at it from the concept of the indian
constitution what they said was that that fundamental right is only enforceable against the government
and government instrumentalities they actually said look in order for for private organizations to be bound by
this right to privacy and this fundamental human right there needed to be legislation involved so the government needed to take the
fact that the court had decided that there was a right to privacy in the indian constitution and then
translate that into laws that would apply to private organizations
so as a result um that precipitated uh the personal data protection bill
which came out at the end of last year december 2019 it was supposed to be passed this
hashtag covered um i think it's still going through when it does eventually get passed it'll
then be implemented in a phased manner but basically the new bill will establish a data protection
authority in india have broad reach including to persons who are based outside of india but who
are doing business in india it will set out the principles for processing personal information
it will require consent for collection and it also specifies biometric data as a
sensitive as a type of sensitive information and what that will mean is that there is a higher threshold required for
biometric data because it is considered sensitive information so that will have more onerous consent
requirements i think it will require um uh affirmative action to consent to giving your biometric data

which i think is a great step forward um then they also have concluded in the new builds right to be forgotten

data subjects to actually restrict the ongoing use or disclosure of
personal information which would include that biometric information
however it's not a rainbows and sunshine there are many exemptions and i think we
